org.jpws.pwslib.data
Class PwsPassphrase

java.lang.Object
  org.jpws.pwslib.data.PwsPassphrase
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.lang.Cloneable
public final class PwsPassphrase
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Cloneable

PwsPassphrase represents a sequence of characters which is especially protected against uncoverage through attacking tools analysing the JVM memory. By the design of the class, there is always a crptographic cipher defined for an instance, ensuring that at any time the passphrase value can be both stored encrypted and retrieved decrypted.

All functions are "waste clean", i.e. after retrieving a decrypted value from an instance, the returned value is the only object in memory produced by this class and containing a decrypted form of the value. It is then in the responsibility of the caller to handle decrypted values with care.

public void setValue(char[] value,
                     int start,
                     int length)

Parameters:
value - defining source for the new value of this instance or null
start - starting offset in value
length - the activated length of value

setEncrypted

protected void setEncrypted(byte[] buffer,
                            int length,
                            PwsCipher cph)
Sets the value of this PP from an encrypted byte buffer and a given cipher. It is assumed that the contents of parameter buffer are encrypted with the specified cipher cph. It is further assumed that the (decrypted) contents of the array are to be interpreted as as sequence of Unicode-16 characters c, each represented by an integer (short)c, stored in Little-Endian (!) representation.

Parameters:
buffer - the new value for this passphrase as encrypted data block; the length of the array must be a multiple of BLOCKSIZE * 2
length - the active length of the intended character sequence; 0..buffer.length/2
cph - PwsCipher that can be used to cryptograph this password's value

getBytes

public byte[] getBytes(java.lang.String enc)
Returns the decrypted value of this passphrase as an array of bytes. The conversion of the internal chars representaion to the sequence of bytes follows the encoding charset as specified by the parameter.

Parameters:
enc - charset encoding standard; null for VM default charset
Returns:
array of bytes containing the encoded sequence of characters forming this passphrase
Throws:
java.nio.charset.IllegalCharsetNameException - if the given charset name is illegal
java.nio.charset.UnsupportedCharsetException - if no support for the named charset is available in this instance of the Java virtual machine

getValue

public char[] getValue()
Returns the decrypted value of this passphrase as an array of char. If this value is void, an array of length 0 is returned.

Returns:
array of char of the active length of he stored value, i.e. identical with getLength()

getValueBuffer

protected byte[] getValueBuffer()
Returns the value of this passphrase as a decrypted version of the internal stored buffer. The content reflects only the active length of passphrase (so the resulting length should be getLength() * 2).

getEncryptedBlock

public byte[] getEncryptedBlock(PwsCipher cph)
Returns the encrypted data block of this passphrase as an array of bytes, encrypted along the cipher as specified by the parameter PwsCipher or by the internal cipher. The resulting array object is always separate from the internal value.

Parameters:
cph - PwsCipher along which the return block will be encrypted; this may differ from the cipher used for storing this value. If null the internal cipher is used instead.
Returns:
encrypted array of bytes; length is a multiple of BLOCKSIZE * 2

getLength

public int getLength()
The length of the stored value in number of characters.

getStringBuffer

public java.lang.StringBuffer getStringBuffer()
Returns the decrypted value of this passphrase as a StringBuffer.

getString

public java.lang.String getString()
Returns the decrypted value of this passphrase as a String. If this value is void, an empty string is returned.

!!WARNING!! this undestoyable uncovered password value constitutes a security threat! It might not be ultimately avoidable though in certain environments, but it should be used as sparing as possible.

isEmpty

public boolean isEmpty()
Whether this object does not store a value (equivalent to getLength()==0).

equals

public boolean equals(java.lang.Object obj)
Whether the parameter passphrase object equals this instance. Two PwsPassphrase objects are equal if and only if their cleartext values are equal.

Overrides:
equals in class java.lang.Object
Parameters:
obj - instance of PwsPassphrase
Returns:
true if and only if obj is not null, of type PwsPassphrase and its cleartext value is identical with the corresponding value of this instance
Throws:
java.lang.ClassCastException - if obj is not of same type

hashCode

public int hashCode()
Returns a hashcode value coherent with equals() for this passphrase, based on its cleartext value.

hashCode in class java.lang.Object

Returns a textual representation of the encrypted stored value.
